User Experience Design

# 

<span key="7cd2f25cf2334fe3a174777bd88ef7f4"><span offset-key="7cd2f25cf2334fe3a174777bd88ef7f4:0">User Experience Design</span></span>

<span key="4d1a72f30e93417da1f5cac0e51e369e"><span offset-key="4d1a72f30e93417da1f5cac0e51e369e:0">I‚Äôve been practicing </span></span><a href="https://semanticstudios.com/publications/semantics/000149.php" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="a8fb30a7845a437fbb24218fe4d6e8cd" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="a7937ac8814d498eb5ec05362ce93376"><span data-offset-key="a7937ac8814d498eb5ec05362ce93376:0">information architecture</span></span></span></a><span key="a09dae870e72436a910810d98d03576c"><span offset-key="a09dae870e72436a910810d98d03576c:0"> since 1994, and from </span></span><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gopher_protocol" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="c2712909015647d28af25167cefe932f" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="e1c35bd52ed2478795b2a8f7bd17d8e9"><span data-offset-key="e1c35bd52ed2478795b2a8f7bd17d8e9:0">Gopher</span></span></span></a><span key="3fe38ad2a25541b89803709e96f4b74e"><span offset-key="3fe38ad2a25541b89803709e96f4b74e:0"> to </span></span><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="1429494c47d34fb5b2c6949694ce98f4" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="723e3c4275dd400698766aa756c94ab6"><span data-offset-key="723e3c4275dd400698766aa756c94ab6:0">Google</span></span></span></a><span key="3819b00e81cb43478816a2b7e6b7a803"><span offset-key="3819b00e81cb43478816a2b7e6b7a803:0"> have seen dramatic changes in the landscape of organization, search and retrieval. Through these ten tempestuous years, I‚Äôve found the infamous three circle diagram to be a great tool for explaining how and why we must strike a unique balance on each project between business goals and context, user needs and behavior, and content.</span></span><a href="https://semanticstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2004/06/threecircles.jpg" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="ca5b8391fe3144cda0e4f47612280990" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="492765dcd6d24e44896c6f51cc30d7ab"><span data-offset-key="492765dcd6d24e44896c6f51cc30d7ab:0"><span data-slate-zero-width="z">‚Äã</span></span></span><span data-slate-void="true" data-key="722b43f901674d33af1f4f293be36389"><span></span></span></span></a>

<span key="5c5d3c65272447989d1b032a4943e087"><span offset-key="5c5d3c65272447989d1b032a4943e087:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">‚Äã</span></span></span><span key="ee4e2331128b40d7aded89fda105ed3d"><span offset-key="ee4e2331128b40d7aded89fda105ed3d:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">‚Äã</span></span></span>

<span key="1095f80f15b74caa88567e3575588d4e"><span offset-key="1095f80f15b74caa88567e3575588d4e:0">Three Circles of Information Architecture</span></span>

<span key="ea7c65cc0cc14739aa3a9f29422202e5"><span offset-key="ea7c65cc0cc14739aa3a9f29422202e5:0">While this diagram was conceived with IA in mind, it‚Äôs equally useful for explaining UX. In conjunction with Jesse‚Äôs </span></span><a href="http://www.jjg.net/ia/elements.pdf" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="f8c60b4a757642448daac764247ef798" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="62453479781d4dfe9ab6f831042c5392"><span data-offset-key="62453479781d4dfe9ab6f831042c5392:0">masterpiece</span></span></span></a><span key="de80a8a9addd4601a84da0b2df03eb9d"><span offset-key="de80a8a9addd4601a84da0b2df03eb9d:0">, I use the three circles to illustrate the distinction between user experience and user-centered design. I‚Äôm still not convinced UCD exists outside the realm of theory, but I practice user experience design every day.</span></span>

<span key="233143b670a94346a11cd24e48fb7660">**Facets of the User Experience**</span>

<span key="1c8c1abc0919476db4170a63ac22970a"><span offset-key="1c8c1abc0919476db4170a63ac22970a:0">When I broadened my interest from IA to UX, I found the need for a new diagram to illustrate the facets of user experience ‚Äì especially to help clients understand why they must move beyond usability ‚Äì and so with a little help from my </span></span><a href="http://qltd.com" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="58162c4247b04ba3a35e7073c14e77b5" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="c90f4759b92d4c73a26e3b3a47b59e43"><span data-offset-key="c90f4759b92d4c73a26e3b3a47b59e43:0">friends</span></span></span></a><span key="df9289a7ff1d45d29879958659e0a816"><span offset-key="df9289a7ff1d45d29879958659e0a816:0"> developed the user experience honeycomb.</span></span><a href="https://semanticstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2004/06/honeycomb.jpg" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="6ff438c95f234d16942c95204a125f50" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="65eb01dc75ab46f4b1e1a1e2e735f10f"><span data-offset-key="65eb01dc75ab46f4b1e1a1e2e735f10f:0"><span data-slate-zero-width="z">‚Äã</span></span></span><span data-slate-void="true" data-key="97d5442d004746d098a47e361aa38b8f"><span></span></span></span></a>

<span key="4b5d264b639f44e1a724919252f66ae0"><span offset-key="4b5d264b639f44e1a724919252f66ae0:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">‚Äã</span></span></span><span key="3c4bc46f17bb4818bf166a671dcff1d7"><span offset-key="3c4bc46f17bb4818bf166a671dcff1d7:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">‚Äã</span></span></span>

<span key="df0a04ec52b84d18bb709bc3a981eb1c"><span offset-key="df0a04ec52b84d18bb709bc3a981eb1c:0">User Experience Honeycomb</span></span>

<span key="73884536c57a4f2c9adb63bc0b9106d7"><span offset-key="73884536c57a4f2c9adb63bc0b9106d7:0">Naturally, the jump from three circles to seven hexagons gave me a buzz, but after months of road testing, I can safely say this diagram has survived the honeymoon.</span></span>

<span key="ab9eca0438df4ce196ee80e110117f78"><span offset-key="ab9eca0438df4ce196ee80e110117f78:0">Here‚Äôs how I explain each facet or quality of the user experience:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="231efbaad19347589fac9ab8fec6472a">**Useful.**<span offset-key="231efbaad19347589fac9ab8fec6472a:1"> As practitioners, we can‚Äôt be content to paint within the lines drawn by managers. We must have the courage and creativity to ask whether our products and systems are useful, and to apply our knowledge of craft + medium to define innovative solutions that are more useful.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="d843de4e26b041f99bbd3da93dfeca4f">**Usable.**<span offset-key="d843de4e26b041f99bbd3da93dfeca4f:1"> Ease of use remains vital, and yet the interface-centered methods and perspectives of human-computer interaction do not address all dimensions of web design. In short, usability is necessary but not sufficient.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="895dbb33fd7f46469fd006af7842a761">**Desirable.**<span offset-key="895dbb33fd7f46469fd006af7842a761:1"> Our quest for efficiency must be tempered by an appreciation for the power and value of image, identity, brand, and other elements of </span></span><a href="http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/0465051359/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="a7c1314210014e8f90e00be023e3d0f4" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="701a6905a50f44a2b129a2fb8995c284"><span data-offset-key="701a6905a50f44a2b129a2fb8995c284:0">emotional design</span></span></span></a><span key="1263489816b14532b7a283fc9826ac1d"><span offset-key="1263489816b14532b7a283fc9826ac1d:0">.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="f1bb5fe51e5c48f89c632d154cf5b96f">**Findable.**<span offset-key="f1bb5fe51e5c48f89c632d154cf5b96f:1"> We must strive to design navigable web sites and locatable objects, so users can find what they need.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="ba71e89eed49422088f785e8db7a3776">**Accessible.**<span offset-key="ba71e89eed49422088f785e8db7a3776:1"> Just as our buildings have elevators and ramps, our web sites should be accessible to people with disabilities (more than 10% of the population). Today, it‚Äôs </span></span><a href="http://www.webstandards.org/learn/reference/web_standards_for_business.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="d9538c7914d44d54b096c453266e335a" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="a3b9047413004991a299d3dd2c861ca2"><span data-offset-key="a3b9047413004991a299d3dd2c861ca2:0">good business</span></span></span></a><span key="922643c6b89743f7b427f4f778bf9cc9"><span offset-key="922643c6b89743f7b427f4f778bf9cc9:0"> and the ethical thing to do. Eventually, it will become the law.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="638c112026ad4b0ca8d6d59a5f500f22">**Credible.**<span offset-key="638c112026ad4b0ca8d6d59a5f500f22:1"> Thanks to the </span></span><a href="http://credibility.stanford.edu" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="02d8adf866434b29af3c972236c35851" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="02cde05073644a00990903c4549e867e"><span data-offset-key="02cde05073644a00990903c4549e867e:0">Web Credibility Project</span></span></span></a><span key="e7b0650befd24b38b1f1d340ee9cdc07"><span offset-key="e7b0650befd24b38b1f1d340ee9cdc07:0">, we‚Äôre beginning to understand the design elements that influence whether users trust and believe what we tell them.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="3e0679ca9902420d84753954840d8f59">**Valuable.**<span offset-key="3e0679ca9902420d84753954840d8f59:1"> Our sites must deliver value to our sponsors. For non-profits, the user experience must advance the mission. With for-profits, it must contribute to the bottom line and improve customer satisfaction.</span></span>

<span key="ae4ee5d370624ddda0ad1dbd5b07794e"><span offset-key="ae4ee5d370624ddda0ad1dbd5b07794e:0">The honeycomb hits the sweet spot by serving several purposes at once. First, it‚Äôs a great tool for advancing the conversation beyond usability and for helping people understand the need to define priorities. Is it more important for your web site to be desirable or accessible? How about usable or credible? The truth is, it depends on your unique balance of context, content and users, and the required tradeoffs are better made explicitly than unconsciously.</span></span>

<span key="b4b01b05dd0e435bb9a7df0f8bb841a8"><span offset-key="b4b01b05dd0e435bb9a7df0f8bb841a8:0">Second, this model supports a modular approach to web design. Let‚Äôs say you want to improve your site but lack the budget, time, or stomach for a complete overhaul. Why not try a targeted redesign, perhaps starting with Stanford‚Äôs </span></span><a href="http://credibility.stanford.edu/guidelines/index.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="9019d48044ae4403a184ff057e15e6e8" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="cfb8fd3f0215489083e8793163ca6094"><span data-offset-key="cfb8fd3f0215489083e8793163ca6094:0">ten guidelines</span></span></span></a><span key="e24894f859574b9b876e889202a8b2af"><span offset-key="e24894f859574b9b876e889202a8b2af:0"> as a resource for evaluating and enhancing the credibility of your web site?</span></span>

<span key="0c7f2793c4254ed1a10aa4df098bd483"><span offset-key="0c7f2793c4254ed1a10aa4df098bd483:0">Third, each facet of the user experience honeycomb can serve as a singular looking glass, transforming how we see what we do, and enabling us to explore beyond conventional boundaries.</span></span>

<span key="646a14c8ea9c4b679a44058ba3a241f3">**A Different Way of Seeing**</span>

<span key="cc786208bcaa4f50a45938d74212521e"><span offset-key="cc786208bcaa4f50a45938d74212521e:0">For example, I realized some time ago that while ‚Äúinformation architect‚Äù describes my profession, </span></span><a href="http://findability.org" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="c42fca3907bf4fe4a633cc8bdbafd3ab" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="fce081149a6b4e68b778780d8c35872e"><span data-offset-key="fce081149a6b4e68b778780d8c35872e:0">findability</span></span></span></a><span key="ee119bf955d641a19ddf592b1f88fd71"><span offset-key="ee119bf955d641a19ddf592b1f88fd71:0"> defines my passion. Since then, I‚Äôve found my focus on findability has opened my eyes, leading me beyond IA while simultaneously making me a better </span></span><a href="http://semanticstudios.com/information_architect/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="b2f222c694ff46ccaf0d4c2c6700d24c" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="75368cf19bd046f980a313a2a4ca07fd"><span data-offset-key="75368cf19bd046f980a313a2a4ca07fd:0">information architect</span></span></span></a><span key="812df984e4f14949880f6ae47006b6aa"><span offset-key="812df984e4f14949880f6ae47006b6aa:0">.</span></span>

<span key="7f3c888030c04c3ea422fdc28bb63af6"><span offset-key="7f3c888030c04c3ea422fdc28bb63af6:0">Last Summer, while redesigning the </span></span><a href="http://qltd.com" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="903381257e154512a6b62d70777e1543" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="b3614a0d82144e10969663ffdfdd4ff0"><span data-offset-key="b3614a0d82144e10969663ffdfdd4ff0:0">Q</span></span></span></a><span key="33090c851a8b458ebc7c2c1a0ea29e65"><span offset-key="33090c851a8b458ebc7c2c1a0ea29e65:0"> web site, we identified findability as a top priority. Our quest to make this small site more findable took me beyond the discipline of information architecture and deep into the realm of search engine optimization.</span></span>

<span key="1d6f988876dd4daa854e4af6efd15003"><span offset-key="1d6f988876dd4daa854e4af6efd15003:0">That experience proved useful last Fall, during a redesign project for the </span></span><a href="http://cancer.gov" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="ee7aa1fb5cc74442a223a4b07aafee34" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="0c478ee32c3e42c78a1959d4fac51f8f"><span data-offset-key="0c478ee32c3e42c78a1959d4fac51f8f:0">National Cancer Institute</span></span></span></a><span key="6994967b604a4fb1a9d69439ad5b8d5f"><span offset-key="6994967b604a4fb1a9d69439ad5b8d5f:0">, in which we used findability concepts and SEO statistics to alleviate an unhealthy fixation on the home page, raising awareness of the need to design findable documents for direct access via the Google, MSN, and Yahoo! search engines.</span></span>

<span key="135bb4bccc5c463faa277877dd3270ce"><span offset-key="135bb4bccc5c463faa277877dd3270ce:0">And this Spring, I was hired to perform my first </span></span><a href="https://semanticstudios.com/consulting/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="0984db8505a14aa3a9bec75136b2c70b" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="6801d3c9a3364c728ef4e52fd77afb7b"><span data-offset-key="6801d3c9a3364c728ef4e52fd77afb7b:0">findability audit</span></span></span></a><span key="e88a783b3ea64efc99026289a5edfc97"><span offset-key="e88a783b3ea64efc99026289a5edfc97:0"> for a major international nonprofit. Feeling a bit concerned about dedicating four weeks exclusively to findability, I asked whether I should also consider usability factors. ‚ÄúNo thanks,‚Äù my client replied. ‚ÄúWe already had </span></span><a href="http://www.useit.com/jakob/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="e702f5916e8545dabaf698942cd085a1" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="5b86f261ec2b4495a9b59d1a28d15933"><span data-offset-key="5b86f261ec2b4495a9b59d1a28d15933:0">Jakob</span></span></span></a><span key="f48e246ad5024eae999a60818b606ba7"><span offset-key="f48e246ad5024eae999a60818b606ba7:0"> in last year to focus on usability.‚Äù</span></span>

<span key="dde404d8fd384cb18d741fbced7681f3">**A Big Hive**</span>

<span key="1ca7dc1e40b145b182c851d2911d4ec9"><span offset-key="1ca7dc1e40b145b182c851d2911d4ec9:0">Though the findability audit was a success, it did feel ironic to once again be ensnared inside a box (or hexagon) of my own making. But I‚Äôm sticking with findability for now. Between my </span></span><a href="https://semanticstudios.com/presentations/iaf/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="3fc4ef44d5ea4c49a1e20f6c99099262" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="2c431b89f7334128abed866377e68405"><span data-offset-key="2c431b89f7334128abed866377e68405:0">new seminar</span></span></span></a><span key="cb78313511d841709c2483c970d0f639"><span offset-key="cb78313511d841709c2483c970d0f639:0">, my new book, and </span></span><a href="http://findability.org" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="e9f026849b1c45718a9fb81d790cb6dc" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="fd67ec8f7258403e88349ef12256241f"><span data-offset-key="fd67ec8f7258403e88349ef12256241f:0">findability.org</span></span></span></a><span key="65fc6c55cab94d21b730b4ef401115e1"><span offset-key="65fc6c55cab94d21b730b4ef401115e1:0">, I‚Äôm busy as a bee. And anytime I feel trapped, I can explore other facets of the user experience honeycomb, or perhaps even create a new diagram. For me, user experience design is a </span></span><a href="http://www.kk.org/outofcontrol/ch2-g.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="3fbe0628c81c46f089f36a2000e3583d" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-6969_259-6970-237__"><span data-key="50fc8484b76a4e73b280c2c3d4df683a"><span data-offset-key="50fc8484b76a4e73b280c2c3d4df683a:0">big hive:</span></span></span></a><span key="b5036c38414b4cbe98c3f8cba8b5ecb2"><span offset-key="b5036c38414b4cbe98c3f8cba8b5ecb2:0"> a dynamic, multi-dimensional space where there‚Äôs still plenty of room to build new boxes and draw new arrows, at least for the next ten years.</span></span>

<a href="../notes.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1awozwy r-14lw9ot r-190qawg r-z2wwpe r-rs99b7 r-4dj0k7 r-1loqt21 r-1quu1zo r-1ro0kt6 r-18u37iz r-16y2uox r-1wbh5a2 r-nsbfu8 r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"></a>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1rasi3h r-1472mwg r-lrsllp" />

CANVAS - Previous

Notes

<a href="user-research.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1awozwy r-14lw9ot r-190qawg r-z2wwpe r-rs99b7 r-4dj0k7 r-1loqt21 r-1quu1zo r-1ro0kt6 r-18u37iz r-16y2uox r-1wbh5a2 r-nsbfu8 r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"></a>
